Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effect of Reverse Bevel Nasotracheal Intubation on Epistaxis

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at Asan Medical Center, Seoul, Korea, from November 2021 to September 2023.

Participants.evidence: Seventy-four patients undergoing right-sided maxillofacial surgery requiring left nasotracheal intubation

Intervention.evidence: randomly allocated to either the control group (conventional tube direction) or the reverse group (180˚ reverse bevel direction)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the effect of a 180˚ reverse bevel and tip direction of the nasotracheal tube on the incidence of epistaxis during left nostril intubation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of epistaxis, assessed via videolaryngoscopy.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using web-based software, with allocation concealment ensured.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Seventy-four patients undergoing right-sided maxillofacial surgery requiring left nasotracheal intubation

Result_Outcome.evidence: relative risk: 0.45, 95% CI [0.24, 0.85], absolute risk reduction: 29.8%, number needed to treat: 3

Harms.evidence: No nasotracheal tube-related complications were reported in either group.
